title: Im toxic, but i feel like I have the right to shit talk these players
body: I got a 10 day chat restriction for perfectly good reason. Im an asshole, my teammates are idiots, and im hot headed. But when illaoi top complains about talon mid ganking top then says i stole xp, I have a god given right to call this player a scum fuck bastard. When someone autolock and steals top, and brand support intetionally steals my red buff, I have the right to tell him to go choke on his own dick. When someone steals my buff because they AA when it's at 14 health, then gives the red buff to the ADC after giving first blood, riot, let me call this player a stromboli dick fuck

I think permanently banning people from the game is actually less healthy in my opinion.

Players were already given:

- 10 games chat restriction 
- 25 games chat restriction
- 14 days suspension

before they get moved to being permanently banned. These punishments are considered their 2nd chances, and most of them were able to reform at a steady rate. Of course you might say "But some players also gets immediately permabanned as their 1st punishment", if that were to happen, it is SERIOUSLY obvious why. Etc telling someone to "k.ys", tons of racial slurs that covers 70% of their chat logs.

Another thing you might add is "Permachat is a better solution". No. Riot did this before, it led to more AFK, troll & Intentional Feeding cases, which is obviously worse. 

You might also add "But you don't know that" or "I not the type to do that, just try it", please stop. It happened, it failed. Additionally, here's Riot Tantram on the perma-chat take:

https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/wsObUaFj-if-tyler1?comment=00010001000000000000

> [{quoted}](name=Riot Tantram,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=wsObUaFj,comment-id=00010001000000000000,timestamp=2017-09-27T02:50:40.483+0000)
>
> It really breaks down into two categories.
> 
> 1.) Helping players reform
> 2.) Shielding others from the behavior, at a cost.
> 
> We used to issue chat restrictions that essentially scaled indefinitely. 
> 
> We were able to determine that after a certain point the penalty no longer helped with reform. The 10-game and 25-game counts for chat restrictions are based on data that they were both light enough, and felt strict enough to encourage people to understand their behavior is unacceptable in game and change it.
> 
> We also saw that the players in this 'large restriction' category defaulted to gameplay altering means of harassing their team. It caused an increase in feeding and trolling.
> 
> The sample size of this population and time frame is huge. Essentially the time spanning from the introduction of chat restrictions to the introduction of IFS.
> 
> So my question for you is, would you rather have more feeders and less negative chat?
